revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1938|film|television|radio }} {{Yearsinfilm}} <!-- SIDEBAR NAV-BOX --> The year '''1938 in film''' involved some significant events.
==Events== *January - [[MGM]] announces that [[Judy Garland]] will be cast in the role of "Dorothy" in the upcoming ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' film. [[Ray Bolger]] is cast as the "Tinman" and [[Buddy Ebsen]] as the "Scarecrow". At Bolger's insistence, the roles are switched between the two actors. On July 25, MGM announces [[Bert Lahr]] has been cast as the "Cowardly Lion". *April 5 - [[Noel Langley]] completes the first script for ''The Wizard of Oz''. *April 20 - Leonard Slye appears in his first starring role as [[Roy Rogers]] in ''[[Under Western Stars]]''. He became one of the most popular [[Western (genre)|Western]] stars being ranked number one from 1943 to 1952 and would become known as "King of the Cowboys". *May 7 - Lyricist [[Edgar Yipsel Harburg]] and composer, [[Harold Arlen]], begin work on the musical score for ''The Wizard of Oz''. *October 13 - Filming starts on ''The Wizard of Oz''. *October 21 - [[Buddy Ebsen]] suffers from a near fatal allergic reaction to the aluminum dust used in his "Tinman" make-up on the set of ''The Wizard of Oz''. Ebsen is replaced by [[Jack Haley]]. *December 23 - [[Margaret Hamilton (actress)|Margaret Hamilton]] is severely burned during a mishap on the set of ''The Wizard of Oz''. Hamilton, who was cast in the role of the "Wicked Witch", leaves the film for six weeks. *[[Orson Welles]] makes ''[[Too Much Johnson]]'', starring [[Joseph Cotten]]. It is never completed and first released only in [[2013 in film|2013]].
==Top-grossing films (U.S.)<ref>Box Office Digest, March 1939, p.18</ref>== At the time, box office numbers were reported as a percentage of business for each theater in comparison to 'normal' business. For example, ''Alexander's Ragtime Band'' performed at 227% and ''The Adventures of Robin Hood'' at 170%. This is why exact dollar grosses for films are unreliable at best. {| class="wikitable" ! {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Year nav topic5|1986|art}}
The year '''1986 in art''' involved some significant events and new works.
==Events== *21 May – Eighteen [[Old Master]] paintings from the [[Sir Alfred Beit, 2nd Baronet|Beit]] collection are stolen from [[Russborough House]] in [[Ireland]] by [[Martin Cahill|Martin "The General" Cahill]], the second major art theft from this location. *19 August – Two weeks after it was stolen, the [[Picasso]] painting ''Weeping Woman'' is found in a locker at [[Southern Cross railway station|Spencer Street station]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]]. *Opening of the [[Musée d'Orsay]] (formerly the [[Gare d'Orsay]]) in [[Paris]].
==Awards== *[[Archibald Prize]]: [[Davida Allen]] – ''Dr John Arthur McKelvey Shera'' *[[Sulman Prize]] – [[Wendy Sharpe]] – ''Black Sun – Morning and Night'' *[[Turner Prize]] – [[Gilbert and George]] **Shortlisted were: [[Art & Language]], [[Victor Burgin]], [[Derek Jarman]], [[Stephen McKenna (artist)|Stephen McKenna]] and [[Bill Woodrow]].
==Works== {{see also|Category:1986 paintings|Category:1986 sculptures}} *David Adickes – ''[[Cornet (sculpture)|Cornet]]'' (sculpture, Galveston, Texas) *[[Ruth Asawa]] – ''[[Aurora (Asawa)|Aurora]]'' (sculpture, San Francisco) *[[John Buckley (sculptor)|John Buckley]] – [[The Headington Shark]] (''Untitled 1986''; painted fibreglass sculpture) *[[Wayne Chabre]] – ''[[Einstein Gargoyle]]'' (sculpture, Eugene, Oregon) *[[John Doubleday]] – Royal Marines Commando Memorial (Lympstone, England) *Georgia Gerber – ''[[Animals in Pools]]'' (sculptures, Portland, Oregon) *[[David Hockney]] – ''Pearblossom Highway #2'' ([[photocollage]]) *[[Ellsworth Kelly]] – ''[[Houston Triptych]]'' (bronze sculpture, Houston, Texas) *[[Igor Mitoraj]] – ''{{Lang|fr|Heros de Lumiere}}'' *[[Odd Nerdrum]] – ''[[Return of the Sun]]'' *Kantilal B. Patel – ''[[Mohandas Gandhi (Patel)|Mohandas Gandhi]]'' (sculpture, New York City) *[[Andrew Wyeth]] – ''[[Flood Plain (painting)|Flood Plain]]'' *[[Jamie Wyeth]] – ''[[Kalounna in Frogtown]]'' (Terra Foundation for American Art) *Yu Tang Wang and Sun Chau – ''[[Chinatown Gateway]]'' (structure, Portland, Oregon)
==Births== ===January to June=== *15 April – Amy Louise Nettleton, British installation and sculpture artist.
==Deaths== ===January to June=== *6 March – [[Georgia O'Keeffe]] American artist (b. [[1887 in art|1887]]). *26 April – [[Dechko Uzunov]], Bulgarian painter (b. [[1899 in art|1899]]). *11 May – [[Henry Plumer McIlhenny]], American art collector, philanthropist and chairman of [[Philadelphia Art Museum]] (b. [[1910 in art|1910]]). *31 May – [[Jane Frank]], American painter, sculptor, [[mixed media]] artist and [[textile artist]] (b. [[1918 in art|1918]]). *9 June – [[Ilona Harima]], [[Finns|Finnish]] painter (b. [[1911 in art|1911]]).
===July to December=== *7 April – [[Cecil King (painter)|Cecil King]], Irish abstract-[[minimalism|minimalist]] painter (b. [[1921 in art|1921]]). *30 June – [[Guan Zilan]], Chinese avant-garde painter (b. [[1903 in art|1903]]) *22 July – [[Floyd Gottfredson]], American [[cartoonist]] (b. [[1905 in art|1905]]). *31 August – [[Henry Moore]], English artist and [[Sculpture|sculptor]] (b. [[1898 in art|1898]]). *9 September – [[Albert Malet (painter)|Albert Malet]], French painter (b. [[1912 in art|1912]]). *12 September **<!--12 September-->[[Jacques Henri Lartigue]], French photographer and painter (b. [[1894 in art|1894]]). **<!--12 September-->[[Ernst Haas]], Austrian photographer (b. [[1921 in art|1921]]). *18 September – [[Corita Kent]], American nun and silkscreen printer (b. [[1918 in art|1918]]). *11 October – [[Barker Fairley]], English-born Canadian painter, writer, and educator (b. [[1887 in art|1887]]). *23 October – [[Conrad O'Brien-ffrench]], British intelligence officer, mountaineer and painter (b.[[1893 in art|1893]]).
===Undated=== *[[Marko Čelebonović]], [[Serbian people|Serbian]] painter (b. [[1902 in art|1902]]). *[[Guan Liang]], [[Chinese people|Chinese]] artist (b. [[1900 in art|1900]]).
== See also == * [[1986 in fine arts of the Soviet Union]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:1986 In Art}} [[Category:1986 in art| ]] [[Category:1986 in arts| ]] [[Category:1980s in art]] [[Category:Years of the 20th century in art]]

revision.comment: copy edit with [[Wikipedia:AutoWikiBrowser/General_fixes|General fixes]]; [[Template:Citation_Style_documentation#url|url trimming]] of identifying info per [[WP:LINKSTOAVOID]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = All Over Me | image = AllOverMeIndieFilm.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = Alex Sichel | producer = [[Dolly Hall]] | writer = Sylvia Sichel | narrator = | starring = [[Alison Folland]]
[[Tara Subkoff]] | music = [[Leisha Hailey]]
Miki Navazio | cinematography = Joe DeSalvo | editing = Sabine Hoffmann | studio = Baldini Pictures
Medusa Pictures
Slam Pictures | distributor = [[Alliance Films]]
[[Fine Line Features]] | released = {{Film date|1997|02||[[Berlin International Film Festival]]|1997|04|25|United States|1998|02|19|Australia}} | runtime = 90 mins. | country = United States | language = English | gross = $150,646 (Domestic) | budget = }} '''''All Over Me''''' is a 1997 [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] directed by Alex Sichel and written by her sister, Sylvia Sichel. Alex Sichel received a grant from the [[Princess Grace Foundation]] to make a film about the [[riot grrrl]] music scene and then asked her sister to collaborate with her.{{cite web | title =Production notes | publisher =Fine Line Features - All Over Me Official Site | url =http://www.finelinefeatures.com/alloverme/prodnote.htm | accessdate =2007-11-04 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071111123053/http://www.finelinefeatures.com/alloverme/prodnote.htm| archivedate= 11 November 2007 | deadurl= no}} The [[soundtrack]] featured musicians and bands such as [[Ani DiFranco]], [[Sleater-Kinney]], [[Babes in Toyland (band)|Babes in Toyland]] and many more. ==Plot== This film focuses on Claude ([[Alison Folland]]), a teenage girl who lives in [[Hell's Kitchen, Manhattan|Hell's Kitchen]], [[New York City]], and is the story of her sexual discovery and budding [[lesbianism]] during [[summer vacation]]. Claude's best friend is Ellen ([[Tara Subkoff]]). Her plan to start a band with Ellen is subverted when Ellen begins dating Mark ([[Cole Hauser]]). Claude discovers that Luke ([[Pat Briggs]]), a gay musician who has just moved into her apartment building, has been stabbed to death in what might have been a [[hate crime]]. Ellen hints at the fact that she was there when Luke was killed, but Claude keeps her mouth shut in order to protect her. Claude then goes to a [[gay bar]] and meets Lucy ([[Leisha Hailey]]), a pink-haired guitarist who is playing in the house band. Claude goes to Lucy's apartment, but freaks out and leaves, returning to her apartment to find Ellen waiting for her. They have a fight which ends with Claude screaming that she would die without Ellen. Claude goes out along with Ellen and Mark on one of their dates; Mark gives Ellen [[Depressant|downers]] which make her violently ill. Claude brings her to the bathroom and forces her to vomit, and Ellen refers to Claude as her "Knight in Shining Armor." Mark is visibly furious but manages to contain himself. Claude leaves and goes to Lucy's apartment again, but leaves after a brief make-out session. On the way home, Claude is ambushed in the street by Mark, who questions her relationship with Ellen. Claude threatens to tell the police about Mark's possible involvement in Luke's death due in large part that she is worried that he is leading Ellen down a dark path. Claude goes home to find Ellen waiting for her. Claude tells her that they need to tell the police about Mark, but Ellen says she would go to jail if they knew about her involvement. Claude says she would never let that happen. Claude kisses Ellen and tells her that she loves her. Ellen tells Claude not to say that, and Claude leaves. The next day, Claude cleans out her room, removing all traces of Ellen. She goes to the police before work. Later, the police comes into her workplace and takes Mark away for questioning. Ellen tells Claude that she hates her. Claude says that she knows, and that she's sorry. Claude then starts seeing Lucy. ==Cast== * [[Alison Folland]] as Claude * [[Tara Subkoff]] as Ellen, Claude's best friend. * [[Cole Hauser]] as Mark, Ellen's boyfriend. * [[Wilson Cruz]] as Jesse, Claude's co-worker at the pizzeria * [[Leisha Hailey]] as Lucy, a guitarist that Claude meets and starts dating. * [[Pat Briggs]] as Luke, gay musician who befriends Claude and Jesse * [[Ann Dowd]] as Anne, Claude's mother. * Gene Canfield as Stewart, Anne's boyfriend. * [[Shawn Hatosy]] as Gus * [[Vincent Pastore]] as Don * David Lee Russek as Dave ==Ratings and distribution== The [[MPAA]] gave ''All Over Me'' an R rating for sexuality and drug use involving teen girls, and for strong language. The film premiered at the 1997 [[Berlin International Film Festival]] where it played in the Panorama section.{{cite web | title =1997 Programme | publisher =[[Berlinale]] | url =http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1997/02_programm_1997/02_Programm_1997.html | accessdate =2007-08-31 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181408/http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1997/02_programm_1997/02_Programm_1997.html| archivedate= 30 September 2007 | deadurl= no}} It went on to show at several festivals including the 1997 Turin International Gay and Lesbian Film Festival and the 1998 Lisbon Gay and Lesbian Film Festival. It opened in American theaters on April 25, 1997 distributed by [[Fine Line Features]].{{cite web | title = All Over Me (1997) | publisher = [[Box Office Mojo]] | url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=alloverme.htm | accessdate =2008-04-15 }} It was released in [[Australia]]n theaters on February 19, 1998. It was released onto [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] [[DVD]] on June 14, 2005 distributed by [[Image Entertainment]]. It was released on [[DVD region code#2|Region 2]] DVD on April 8, 2002 distributed by Millivres Multimedia.{{cite web | title =All Over Me (1997) DVD | publisher =[[Amazon.co.uk]] | url =https://www.amazon.co.uk/All-Over-Me-Alison-Folland/dp/B000063VB1/ | accessdate = }} ==Reception== ===Critical=== Critical response to ''All Over Me'' was generally positive. [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives it a "fresh" rating of 84% based on 25 reviews.{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/all_over_me/ |title=All Over Me |accessdate=2007-08-01 |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes}} Critics were impressed with this directorial debut and described it as powerful and conspicuously well-made.{{cite web | last =Levy | first =Emanuel | authorlink =Emanuel Levy | title =Film Review - All Over Me | publisher =EmanuelLevy.com | url =http://emanuellevy.com/article.php?articleID=2763 | accessdate =2007-08-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070927184316/http://emanuellevy.com/article.php?articleID=2763| archivedate= 27 September 2007 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web | last =Maslin | first =Janet | authorlink =Janet Maslin | title =All Over Me (1996) - Friendship Bent by Gender | work =[[The New York Times]] | date =1997-04-25 | url =http://movies2.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=950DE5D9113EF936A15757C0A961958260 | accessdate =2007-08-26 }} They praised the Sichel sisters for telling a story of adolescence and friendship which is at once honest, realistic and authentic, while remaining subtle, subdued and compassionate.{{cite web | last =Guthmann | first =Edward | title =Teens as They Really Are - ''All Over Me'' gets inside adolescent girls' troubled world | work =[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date =1997-04-25 | url =http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1997/04/25/DD27418.DTL | accessdate = 2007-08-26 }}{{cite web | last =Muskewitz | first =Greg | title =All Over Me - Talent All Around | publisher =EFilmCritic.com | url =http://efilmcritic.com/review.php?movie=366&reviewer=172 | accessdate =2007-08-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071007075958/http://efilmcritic.com/review.php?movie=366&reviewer=172| archivedate= 7 October 2007 | deadurl= no}} [[Emanuel Levy]] called it complex and interesting, and Marjorie Baumgarten called it a film for "[[riot grrrl]]s of all ages".{{cite web | last =Baumgarten | first =Marjorie | title =All Over Me | work =[[The Austin Chronicle]] | date =1997-07-04 | url =http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Calendar/Film?Film=oid%3a142300 | accessdate =2007-08-16 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070813011044/http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Calendar/Film?Film=oid%3A142300| archivedate= 13 August 2007 | deadurl= no}} [[Janet Maslin]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised it as a confident first feature but said that it has more style than substance. Its detractors included Don Willmot, who found it melodramatic, and ''[[E!]]'', which described it as titillating but contrived; "a walk on the mild side".{{cite web |last = Willmott |first = Don |title = All Over Me Movie Review |publisher = FilmCritic.com |year = 2005 |url = http://www.filmcritic.com/misc/emporium.nsf/reviews/All-Over-Me |accessdate = 2007-08-26 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071209012248/http://www.filmcritic.com/misc/emporium.nsf/reviews/All-Over-Me |archivedate = 2007-12-09 |df = }}{{cite web | title =All Over Me - E! Reviews | publisher =[[E!]] Online | url =http://www.eonline.com/movies/e_reviews/index.jsp?uuid=3005b310-f644-428c-ac4d-4ea3b6c8c861 | accessdate =2007-08-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930184440/http://www.eonline.com/movies/e_reviews/index.jsp?uuid=3005b310-f644-428c-ac4d-4ea3b6c8c861| archivedate= 30 September 2007 | deadurl= no}} Alison Folland was widely praised by critics for her performance as Claude. Emanuel Levy called her an instinctive actress who "dominates every frame of the picture". Janet Maslin said Folland brings a "wistful sincerity" to the role. Tara Subkoff was also praised for a performance compared by some to [[Rosanna Arquette]]. Not all the critics liked her portrayal of Ellen; ''E!'' called her "merely grating". With its coming-of-age theme and exploration of teenage sexuality, ''All Over Me'' drew comparisons from critics to other films, in particular [[Larry Clark]]'s ''[[Kids (film)|Kids]]'' and [[Maria Maggenti]]'s ''[[The Incredibly True Adventure of Two Girls in Love]]'', both from 1995.{{cite web | last =Russo | first =Lea | title =All Over Me Review | publisher =BoxOffice.com | url =http://www.boxoffice.com/moviedetail.aspx?movieid=170&flag=New | accessdate =2007-08-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070928062126/http://www.boxoffice.com/moviedetail.aspx?movieid=170&flag=New| archivedate= 28 September 2007 | deadurl= no}} Although similarities were noted, ''All Over Me'' was praised for its differences to these two films. ''E!'' called it gentler than ''Kids'', and Muskewitz said ''All Over Me'' was less exploitative than that film. Emanual Levy described it as the far more interesting and complex of the two. Ron Wells said "thank god it's not ''Kids''" and Bernstein said that "comparison misses the point".{{cite web | last =Wells | first =Ron | title =All Over Me Review | publisher =FilmThreat.com | date =1997-04-14 | url =http://www.filmthreat.com/index.php?section=reviews&Id=1192 | accessdate =2007-08-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930165618/http://www.filmthreat.com/index.php?section=reviews&Id=1192| archivedate= 30 September 2007 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web | last =Bernstein | first =Nell | title =The Truth About Girls | publisher =[[Salon.com]] | date =1997-04-25 | url =http://www.salon.com/april97/alloverme970425.html | accessdate =2007-08-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070814022906/http://www.salon.com/april97/alloverme970425.html| archivedate= 14 August 2007 | deadurl= no}} When comparing it to ''[[The Incredibly True Adventure of Two Girls in Love]]'', Emanuel Levy called ''All Over Me'' "much more accomplished". SplicedWire called it " an ideal companion feature for [[Todd Solondz]]'s ''[[Welcome to the Dollhouse]]'', another female-centred coming-of-age film from the mid-1990s.{{cite web | title =All Over Me Review | publisher =SplicedWire.com | url =http://splicedwire.com/97reviews/alloverme.html | accessdate = 2007-08-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071006125119/http://splicedwire.com/97reviews/alloverme.html| archivedate= 6 October 2007 | deadurl= no}} ===Awards=== ''All Over Me'' won the [[Teddy Award]] for Best Feature Film at the 1997 Berlin International Film Festival.{{cite web | title =TEDDY TWENTY TRIBUTE - Berlinale to celebrate the TEDDY with a programme of 36 films | publisher =[[Berlinale]] | date =2005-12-14 | url =http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/2006/08_pressemitteilungen_2006/08_Pressemitteilungen_2006-Detail_2645.html | accessdate =2007-08-31 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930203340/http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/2006/08_pressemitteilungen_2006/08_Pressemitteilungen_2006-Detail_2645.html| archivedate= 30 September 2007 | deadurl= no}} It was nominated for the Grand Jury Prize at the 1997 [[Sundance Film Festival]], the Open Palm Award at the 1997 [[Gotham Awards]] and the Outstanding Film (Limited Release) Award at the 1998 [[GLAAD Media Awards]]. Alison Folland was nominated for the [[Independent Spirit Awards|Independent Spirit Award]] for Best Female Lead. ==Music== The [[film score]] for ''All Over me'' was composed by [[Miki Navazio]].{{cite web | title =Filmmaker Biographies | publisher =Fine Line Features - All Over Me Official Site | url =http://www.finelinefeatures.com/alloverme/prodnote.htm | accessdate =2008-04-15 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080412031911/http://www.finelinefeatures.com/alloverme/prodnote.htm| archivedate= 12 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} The soundtrack to the film was released on the [[TVT Records|TVT]] label on April 29, 1997.{{cite web | title = All Over Me > Overview | publisher = [[Allmusic]] | url = {{Allmusic|class=album|id=r261750|pure_url=yes}} | accessdate =2008-04-15 }} It features songs from several [[indie music|indie]] and [[riot grrl]] musicians interspersed with parts of Navazio's score. {{Infobox album | name = All Over Me | type = soundtrack | artist = | cover = | alt = | released = April 29, 1997 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = | label = [[TVT Records|TVT]] | producer = Bill Coleman, Alex Sichel | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1score = {{Rating|4|5}} {{Allmusic|class=album|id=r261750}} }} ===Track listing=== # "Hello" ([[Lori Barbero]], [[Kat Bjelland]], [[Maureen Herman]]) performed by [[Babes in Toyland (band)|Babes in Toyland]] # "Ellen and Claude Jammin" ([[Miki Navazio]]) # "Shy" performed by [[Ani Difranco]] # "Hole In The Ground" ([[Mary Timony]]) performed by [[Helium (band)|Helium]] # "I Wanna Be Your Joey Ramone" ([[Corin Tucker]], [[Lora McFarlane]]) performed by [[Sleater-Kinney]] # "Game Song" ([[Tuscadero]]) performed by Tuscadero # "Jackie Blue" ([[Larry Lee (musician)|Larry Lee]], [[Steve Cash]]) performed by [[The Ozark Mountain Daredevils]] # "Claude Sees Ellen And Mark" (Navazio) # "Squeezebox Days" ([[Leisha Hailey]]) performed by [[The Murmurs]] # "Dragon Lady" ([[Carla Bozulich]], Daniel Keenan, [[Kevin Fitzgerald (musician)|Kevin Fitzgerald]], [[William Tutton]]) performed by [[Geraldine Fibbers]] # "Dynamite" ([[Alison Pipitone]]) performed by Pipitone # "Empty Glasses" ([[Kim Deal]]) performed by [[The Amps]] # "Descent" ([[Remy Zero]]) performed by Remy Zero # "6 a.m. Jullander Shere" ([[Tjinder Singh]]) performed by [[Cornershop (band)|Cornershop]] # "The Kiss" (Navazio) # "Dimming Soul" ([[Michelle Malone]]) performed by Malone # "[[Pissing in a River]]" ([[Patti Smith]], [[Ivan Kral]]) performed by [[Patti Smith|Patti Smith Group]] # "Superglider" ([[Isabel Monteiro]], [[Daron Robinson]]) performed by [[Drugstore (band)|Drugstore]] # "Finale" (Navazio) # "Something's Burning" ([[12 Rounds]]) performed by 12 Rounds ==See also== * [[List of LGBT films directed by women]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.finelinefeatures.com/alloverme/}} * {{IMDb title|id=0118586|title=All Over Me}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|all_over_me|All Over Me}} * {{Amg movie|136489|All Over Me}} {{Teddy Award for Best Film}} [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:1997 films]] [[Category:American coming-of-age films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American teen drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films set in New York City]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] [[Category:LGBT-related coming-of-age films]] [[Category:1990s LGBT-related films]] [[Category:American teen LGBT-related films]]

page.title: Archive of Performances of Greek and Roman Drama

revision.comment: Added ref to director, links, ce
revision.text:
{{Infobox institute |name = APGRD | image = APGRD(Archive-of-Performances-of-Greek-and-Roman-Drama)-logo.jpg |image_name = APGRD Logo |image_alt = APGRD Logo |non-profit_slogan = ''Research, Preserve, Create'' |head = [[Fiona Macintosh]]<ref name="APGRD" /> |head_label = Director |established = {{Start date|1996}} |founder = [[Edith Hall]] and [[Oliver Taplin]] |focus = performances of Greek and Roman drama and epic, translation of Greek and Roman drama, performance reception |faculty = Classics, [[University of Oxford]] |location = Ioannou Centre for Classical and Byzantine Studies, Oxford |website = {{URL | http://www.apgrd.ox.ac.uk}} }} The '''Archive of Performances of Greek and Roman Drama''' ('''APGRD''') is a research project based at the [[University of Oxford]], [[England]], founded in 1996 by [[Edith Hall]] and [[Oliver Taplin]].<ref name="APGRD">{{ cite web | url=http://www.apgrd.ox.ac.uk/about-us/history | title = APGRD website - About us - History }}</ref> The current Director is [[Fiona Macintosh]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apgrd.ox.ac.uk/about-us/people|title=People {{!}} APGRD|website=www.apgrd.ox.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-17}}</ref>
==Overview== The APGRD's focus is the study of performances of ancient drama and epic worldwide, ranging from the original performances in antiquity to the present day.<ref name="APGRD"/> It also runs a number of programmes promoting new writing and performance, including the 2005–2011 '''Onassis Programme''', which commissioned, developed and produced professional work from artists from around the world, including [[Seamus Heaney]] and [[Derek Walcott]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.onassis.ox.ac.uk/Onassis%20Past%20Events.html | title = The Onassis Programme, Past Productions}}</ref>
The APGRD was praised by Oxford University for its engagement with authors, directors and other theatre practitioners, and was selected as one of the university's ''Impacts'' showcase projects for helping to "sustain the distinctive and dynamic nature of the UK theatre".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/research/research_impact/oxford_impacts/theatre.html | title= Oxford Impacts: Influencing Contemporary Theatre Practice | publisher= [[Oxford University]] }}</ref> The project’s publications have been described as playing "a pivotal role in establishing the parameters and methodologies of the study of the reception of Classical drama in performance".<ref>Hallie Rebecca Marshall, ''[http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2006/2006-09-11.html Bryn Mawr Classical Review]'', 11 September 2006.</ref>
==Archival collections== The APGRD maintains and preserves a number of archival collections.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.apgrd.ox.ac.uk/research-collections | title = APGRD - Research collections }}</ref> The centrepiece is the APGRD's own research archive, a collection of material relating to modern performances of ancient drama. The APGRD also holds a number of other collections, including:
* ''The Leyhausen-Spiess Collection'' - the collected papers of German director and academic Wilhelm Leyhausen,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://homepages.uni-tuebingen.de/gerd.simon/ChrLeyhausen.pdf | title = Chronologie Leyhausen, Wilhelm }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www2.open.ac.uk/ClassicalStudies/GreekPlays/newvoices/issue%25203/Ioannidou.doc | title = Monumental texts in ruins: Greek tragedy in Greece and Michael Mamarinos's modern stagings | publisher = New Voices in Classical Reception Studies, Issue 3 (2008) }}</ref> founder of the Delphic Institute.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/03634526209377237 | title = Choric‐speaking in Greek tragedies performed by students | publisher = The Speech Teacher. Volume 11, Issue 4 (1962) }}</ref> * ''The David Raeburn Collection'' - a collection of papers and records (including promptbooks) belonging to classicist and translator David Raeburn,<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.new.ox.ac.uk/fellows/david.raeburn | title = Faculty page for David Raeburn at New College, Oxford }}</ref><ref>{{ cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2004/feb/14/featuresreviews.guardianreview24 | title=Change is in the air - Nicholas Lezard is excited by David Raeburn's new verse translation of Ovid's Metamorphoses | publisher = [[The Guardian]] | accessdate = 29 November 2011 | location=London | date=14 February 2004}}</ref> who also produced the [[Bradfield College#The Greek Play|Bradfield School Greek play]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.bradfieldcommunity.org.uk/SiteCollectionImages/J.%20Prince/OB%20News%20Spring%202011.pdf | title = The Old Bradfieldian, Spring 2011, p.16 }}</ref> * ''The Abd'Elkader Farrah collection'' - designs and artwork for several of the Greek and Shakespearian productions of the Algerian theatre designer Abd'Elkader Farrah (also known as Abdel Farrah).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.algerianembassy.org.uk/News_KT_AF.htm | title = Message of Sympathy from Khalida Toumi to the children of Abdelkader Farrah | publisher = Embassy of Algeria }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Hands | first = Terry | contribution = Farrah, Abd'Elkader (1926–2005) | title = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/96897 | publisher = Oxford University Press | place = Oxford | year = 2009 | contribution-url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/96897 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/jan/05/guardianobituaries.artsobituaries | accessdate = 5 December 2011 | title = Abdel Farrah - Visionary theatre designer for the RSC for three decades| publisher = The Guardian | location=London | first=Terry | last=Hands | date=5 January 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/features/backstage/feature.php/11188/abdel-farrah | accessdate = 5 December 2011 | title = Abdel Farrah (Obituary) | publisher = The Stage | date= 9 January 2006}}</ref> In addition, the APGRD's performance database has records covering more than 10,000 modern productions of ancient drama and epic.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.apgrd.ox.ac.uk/research-collections/performance-database | title = APGRD website - Research collections - Database}}</ref>
==Selected publications== A number of books have been published under the auspices of the APGRD. These include:<ref name="Publications">{{ cite web | url=http://www.apgrd.ox.ac.uk/publications | title = APGRD website - Publications }}</ref>
*"The Pronomos Vase and its Contexts", edited by [[Oliver Taplin]] and Rosie Wyles ([[Oxford University Press|OUP]], 2010) *"Ancient Drama in Music for the Modern Stage", edited by Peter Brown and Suzana Ograjenšek ([[Oxford University Press|OUP]], 2010) *"The Ancient Dancer in the Modern World: Responses to Greek and Roman Dance", edited by [[Fiona Macintosh]] ([[Oxford University Press|OUP]], 2010) *"Theorising Performance: Greek Tragedy, Cultural History and Critical Practice", edited by [[Edith Hall]] and Stephe Harrop (Duckworth, 2010) *"Oedipus Tyrannus", by [[Fiona Macintosh]] ([[Cambridge University Press]], 2009) *"New Directions in Ancient Pantomime", edited by [[Edith Hall]] and Rosie Wyles ([[Oxford University Press|OUP]], 2008) *"Pots and Plays: Interactions between Tragedy and Greek Vase-painting of the Fourth Century BC", by [[Oliver Taplin]] (Getty Publications, 2007) *"Aristophanes in Performance, 421 BC to AD 2007: Peace, Birds, and Frogs", edited by [[Edith Hall]] and Amanda Wrigley (Oxford: Legenda, forthcoming in 2007) *"Agamemnon in Performance: 458 BC to AD 2004", edited by [[Fiona Macintosh]], Pantelis Michelakis, [[Edith Hall]], and [[Oliver Taplin]] ([[Oxford University Press|OUP]], 2005) *"Greek Tragedy and the British Theatre, 1660-1914", by [[Edith Hall]] and [[Fiona Macintosh]] ([[Oxford University Press|OUP]], 2005) *"Dionysus Since 69: Greek Tragedy at the Dawn of the Third Millennium", edited by [[Edith Hall]], [[Fiona Macintosh]], and Amanda Wrigley ([[Oxford University Press|OUP]], 2004) *"Medea in Performance, 1500-2000", edited by [[Edith Hall]], [[Fiona Macintosh]], and [[Oliver Taplin]] (Legenda, Oxford, 2000)
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further references== *Martina Treu, ''Aristofane Sottosopra'', a review of the APGRD's 'Aristophanes in Performance' conference, Quaderni di Storia 61 (2005), pp. 283–30. *''Chorus of Approval'', Oxford Today: The University Magazine 17.1 (2004), p. 5. *Detlev Baur, ''Antikes Theater heute: Kongress in Oxford zur Bühnengeschichte des Agamemnon'', a review of the APGRD's Agamemnon conference, Landshuter Zeitung, 20 September 2001.
==External links== *[http://www.apgrd.ox.ac.uk/ APGRD (Archive of Performances of Greek and Roman Drama)] *{{cite web | url=http://chronicle.com/blogs/arts/greek-theater-tradition-alive-and-well-at-uk-colleges/28617 | title=Greek Theater Tradition Alive and Well at UK Colleges | publisher=The Chronicle of Higher Education | date = 8 February 2011 | accessdate = 29 November 2011 }} *{{cite web | url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/research/research_impact/oxford_impacts/theatre.html | title= Oxford Impacts: Influencing Contemporary Theatre Practice | publisher= [[Oxford University]] }} *{{cite web | url=http://www.didaskalia.net/issues/vol6no2/wrigley.htm | title = The APGRD Database of Modern Performances of Ancient Drama at the University of Oxford | publisher = Didaskalia - The Journal for Ancient Performance }} *[http://www.onassis.ox.ac.uk The Onassis Programme ] {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1996 establishments in England]] [[Category:Archives in Oxfordshire]] [[Category:Research projects]] [[Category:Culture of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:Performing arts education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Ancient Greek theatre]] [[Category:Ancient Roman theatre]]

revision.text:
{{Italic title}} [[File:Royal Gold Cup with flash.JPG|thumb|330px|The [[Royal Gold Cup]], 23.6 cm high, 17.8 cm across at its widest point; weight 1.935 kg. [[British Museum]]]]
'''''Basse-taille''''' (bahss-tah-ee) is an [[Vitreous enamel|enamelling]] technique in which the artist creates a low-relief pattern in metal, usually [[silver]] or [[gold]], by [[engraving]] or [[Repoussé and chasing|chasing]]. The entire pattern is created in such a way that its highest point is lower than the surrounding metal. A [[translucent]] enamel is then applied to the metal, allowing light to reflect from the relief and creating an artistic effect. It was used in the late Middle Ages, and then again in the 17th century.
==Medieval examples== [[File:Medallion bull St Luke MNMA Cl14719.jpg|thumb|300px|A 14th-century silver plaque in ''basse-taille'' with translucent enamels, with considerable losses, showing the prepared metal surfaces beneath, and the tinting with different colours.]] The technique had been known to the Ancient Romans, but was lost at the end of the Middle Ages until the 17th century.<ref>"British Museum Investigation"; Lightbown; Maryon (1971), 188; Osbourne, 333</ref> Translucent enamel is more fragile than opaque, and medieval survivals in good condition are very rare. Medieval examples begin in Italy in the 13th century, with the earliest dated work being a chalice by the Sienese goldsmith [[Guccio di Mannaia]], made for [[Pope Nicholas IV]] about 1290, which is part of the collection of the [[Treasure Museum of the basilica of Saint Francis in Assisi]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Colum|first1=Hourihane|title=The Grove Encyclopedia of Medieval Art and Architecture, Volume 2|date=2012|publisher=OUP USA|isbn=0195395360|page=93|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FtlMAgAAQBAJ&pg=RA2-PA93&lpg=RA2-PA93&dq=guccio+di+mannaia+basse-taille#v=onepage&q=guccio%20di%20mannaia%20basse-taille&f=false|accessdate=18 November 2016}}</ref>
The technique then spread to other centres for high-quality courtly work, at a time when the [[champlevé]] enamels associated above all with [[Limoges]] had become almost mass-produced and relatively cheap. It is generally agreed that the late 14th century [[Royal Gold Cup]], now in the [[British Museum]], is the outstanding surviving example of ''basse taille'' enamel.<ref>Osbourne, 333</ref> It is one of only four known survivals done on gold, including both secular or religious pieces; another is the small [[George Salting|Salting]] [[Reliquary]], also in the British Museum.<ref>Dalton, 11. The [https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/r/reliquary_pendant,_holy_thorn.aspx "Salting Reliquary"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018024047/https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_mla/r/reliquary_pendant%2C_holy_thorn.aspx |date=October 18, 2015 }}, British Museum Highlights, accessed, June 16, 2010.</ref> The "King John Cup" in [[King's Lynn]], of ca. 1340, silver-gilt with transparent enamel, is the best example of ''basse-taille'' work probably made in England; the metalwork expert [[Herbert Maryon]] describes this and the Royal Gold Cup as the "two examples of outstanding merit, unsurpassed in any collection".<ref>"Maryon (1971)";Alexander & Binski, #541</ref> However it is unclear if most of the enamel at King's Lynn is original.<ref>"Maryon (1971)", 187; ([https://archive.is/20120805235436/http://www.west-norfolk.gov.uk/images/Regalia%2007.jpg Poor image of King John Cup from West Norfolk Council]). See Campbell, 435-436, with good photo and full catalogue entry; Osbourne, 333. Four restorations and re-enamellings between 1692 and 1782 are recorded in inscriptions under the base - see Campbell.</ref>
The technique was rediscovered in the 17th century, but was not much practiced thereafter. In a variant of the technique, translucent enamel was applied over a [[guilloché]] machine-turned metal backing by [[Peter Carl Fabergé]] on the [[Faberge eggs]] and other pieces from the 1880s until the Russian Revolution, and this technique is still used, usually in a single colour.<ref>Marit Guinness Aschan and Rika Smith McNally. "Enamel." In Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online, [https://archive.is/20120910225451/http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T026009 Subscription required] (accessed July 28, 2010).</ref>
==17th century== The revived technique was used in the 17th century for the covers and faces of [[pocket watch]]es, [[gold box]]es and similar items, but mostly with opaque enamel, achieving a rather different effect from medieval examples using translucent enamel. The French watchmaker [[Josias Jolly]] made frequent use of it.
==Technique== [[File:PlacaDormicion MAN.JPG|right|thumb|left|Medallion of the [[Death of the Virgin]], with damaged ''basse-taille'' enamel]]
The process for creating ''basse-taille'' enamel began by marking the outline of the design and the main internal outlines on the gold with a tool called a "tracer". Then the interior area was worked, either with [[Repoussé and chasing|chasing tools]], hammering and punching rather than cutting, or with [[chisel]]s, to form a shallow recess to hold the enamel. The more important parts of the design were modelled by varying the depth of the surface to produce different intensities of colour when the translucent enamel was added; for example in the Royal Gold Cup the gold under folds of drapery often rises near the surface to create a paler highlight. In the example illustrated with Luke's ox the lowest lobe shows tufts of grass formed by cutting deeper into the background. In many of the recessed areas further decoration was added by either engraving or punching which would show through the translucent enamel, or to facet the background so the reflections change as the viewing angle changes slightly. Most background areas to the enamelled scenes were decorated in the same way. Finally the surfaces were cleaned up, made good and polished, perhaps including scraping off any bumps showing through on the reverse of the metal.<ref>Lightbown. Maryon (1951) - see further reading - and his colleagues established the method for making the recesses; Read and Dalton had thought they were cut out with [[chisel]]s. For other objects with translucent enamels, see Campbell, 458-461.</ref>
The enamel lies flush with the gold surfaces; it was a preparation of finely ground glass paste applied with great care to the prepared recessed areas, and then fired. When different colours of enamel meet each other with a neat boundary, this was achieved by firing one colour with a retaining border of [[gum tragacanth]] before adding the next. The difficulty was often increased by the application of tints of a different colour to a base shade of enamel before firing, so that the added colour blends gradually into the background colour around the edges of the tinted area. This is especially used on "flux", or colourless enamel, as in the ground areas, rocks and trees. In the Royal Gold Cup, flux was also used for flesh areas as on a gold background it darkens slightly when hard to a suitable colour for skin. The ''rouge clair'' or "ruby glass" red, used so effectively here, was made by adding tiny particles of [[copper]], silver and gold to the glass; here scientific tests have shown that copper was used. After firing the enamel was polished flush with the surrounding metal, which was presumably decorated last.
==Notes==
{{reflist}}
==References== *Jonathan Alexander & Paul Binski (eds), ''Age of Chivalry, Art in Plantagenet England, 1200–1400'', Royal Academy/Weidenfeld & Nicolson, London 1987; most of the best English examples up to 1400 are catalogue numbers 541, 543, 580-587, 608-610 *[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/article_index/i/investigation_royal_gold_cup.aspx "British Museum Investigation"] ''Investigation of the 'rouge clair' glass on the Royal Gold Cup'' webpage, accessed June 16, 2010 *Campbell, Marian, in Jonathan Alexander & Paul Binski (eds), ''Age of Chivalry, Art in Plantagenet England, 1200-1400'', Royal Academy/Weidenfeld & Nicolson, London 1987 *"Maryon (1951)": [[Herbert Maryon|Maryon, Herbert]], ''New Light on the Royal Gold Cup'', ''The British Museum Quarterly'', Vol. 16, No. 2, April 1951, [https://www.jstor.org/pss/4422320 JSTOR] *"Maryon (1971)": [[Herbert Maryon|Maryon, Herbert]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=AOP_RiQE6-AC&pg=PA187&dq=%22king+john+cup%22+King%27s+Lynn&hl=en&ei=G-EaTKu3KI_00gS_xsiBCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22king%20john%20cup%22%20King%27s%20Lynn&f=false ''Metalwork and enamelling: a practical treatise on gold and silversmiths' work and their allied crafts''], Courier Dover Publications, 1971, {{ISBN|0-486-22702-2}}, {{ISBN|978-0-486-22702-3}} *Osborne, Harold (ed), ''The Oxford Companion to the Decorative Arts'', 1975, OUP, {{ISBN|0-19-866113-4}}
{{commons category|Basse-taille enamel}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Basse-Taille}} [[Category:Decorative arts]] [[Category:Jewellery making]] [[Category:Artistic techniques]] [[Category:Vitreous enamel]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.4.2)
revision.text:
The '''biographical fallacy''' is a term used in cultural criticism to critique the view that works of creative art, literature or music can be interpreted as reflections of the life of their authors.{{cite book|last=Winslow|first=Donald J.|authorlink=Donald James Winslow|title=Life-writing: a glossary of terms in biography, autobiography, and related forms|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|date=1995|edition=2|page=7}} Along with the [[intentional fallacy]], the term was introduced by exponents of the [[New Criticism]] who wished to emphasise that artworks should be interpreted and assessed as constructed artifacts rather than expressions of the emotions of specific individuals. The term is thus used to criticize the school of literary interpretation called [[Biographical criticism]]. The argument arose from the increasing tendency of critics during the 19th century to view artworks in terms of the life experiences of their creators, whether their personal lives, or the wider historical conditions represented in the artist's world view, a claim associated with critics such as [[Hippolyte Taine]].Wolfenstein, Martha, "The Social Background of Taine's Philosophy of Art," Journal of the History of Ideas, Vol. 5, No. 3. (1944), 335. This position{{ref}} was referred to as a "fallacy" on the grounds that it neglected both the purely imaginative aspects of the arts and their reliance on formal conventions and rules of [[genre]]. Thus James M. Thomas writes of the fallacy applied to drama that,
This type of approach distances itself from the play and goes instead into the playwright's biography to find people, places and things that seem to be similar to features in the play. And then it claims that the play is actually a picture of these people, places and things. In its extreme form this is fallacy because it does not consider that playwrights use their imagination when they write and that they can imagine improbable or even impossible things. Thomas, James, ''Script Analysis for Actors, Directors, and Designers'', Focal Press, 2009, p,xxxix.
Robert S. Miola, Professor of English at Loyola College in Maryland, discusses the biographical fallacy as "the unqualified conviction that one can read the author's life from the work and vice versa", and adds:
This fallacy is widespread in Shakespeare studies, true enough, but the business of wrenching passages out of dramatic context as evidence of the playwright's personal beliefs usually reveals more about the critic than about Shakespeare. {{cite web |url=http://www.firstthings.com/article/2008/09/001-thy-canonized-bones-8 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122020202/http://www.firstthings.com/article/2008/09/001-thy-canonized-bones-8 |archivedate=2010-01-22 |df= }}
Commenting further on the fallacy as applied to contemporary work about Shakespeare, Joseph Pearce asserts that "For the proponents of ‘queer theory' he becomes conveniently homosexual; for secular fundamentalists he is a proto-secularist, ahead of his time; for ‘post-Christian' agnostics he becomes a prophet of modernity.” ''The Quest For Shakespeare: The Bard of Avon and the Church of Rome''{{cite web |url=http://www.firstthings.com/article/2008/09/001-thy-canonized-bones-8 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122020202/http://www.firstthings.com/article/2008/09/001-thy-canonized-bones-8 |archivedate=2010-01-22 |df= }} Others consider the term offensive and defend biographical criticism in its non-extreme forms, finding that full understanding of an author's works is not possible without extrinsic sources. Leon Edel in his book ''Literary Biography''Edel Leon (1957) ''Literary Biography'' University of Toronto Press, Toronto, {{OCLC|1027892}} devoted a chapter to defending biographical criticism.Wegelin, Christof (1963) "Jamesian Biography" ''Nineteenth-Century Fiction'' 18(3): pp. 283-287, page 286 While admitting the excesses of certain earlier critics use of biography,Edel (1957) page 69 he rigorously stated that ''no critic, I hold, can explicate—the very word implies this—anything without alluding to something else [outside the work].''Edel (1957) page 63 The term '''inverted autobiography''' is also applied to the practice.Winslow (1995: 34) ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Literary criticism]] [[Category:New Criticism]]

{{Infobox film | name = Black Christmas | image = File:Black Christmas (1974) poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Bob Clark]] | producer = [[Bob Clark]] | writer = A. Roy Moore | starring = [[Olivia Hussey]]
[[Keir Dullea]]
[[Margot Kidder]]
[[John Saxon]] | music = Carl Zittrer | cinematography = Reginald H. Morris | editing = Stan Cole | studio = Film Funding Limited of Canada
Ambassador Films | distributor = Ambassador Film Distributors (Canada)
[[Warner Bros.]] (United States) | released = {{start date|1974|10|11}} {{small|(Canada)}}
{{start date|1974|12|20}} {{small|(U.S.)}} | runtime = 98 minutes{{sfn|Muir|2011|p=314}} | country = Canada | language = English | budget = $620,000 | gross = $4 million }} '''''Black Christmas''''' is a 1974 Canadian [[psychological horror|psychological]] [[slasher film]] produced and directed by [[Bob Clark]], and written by A. Roy Moore. It stars [[Olivia Hussey]], [[Keir Dullea]], [[Margot Kidder]], [[Andrea Martin]], [[Marian Waldman]] and [[John Saxon]]. The story concerns a group of sorority sisters who receive threatening phone calls and are eventually stalked and murdered by a deranged killer during the [[Christmas]] season. Inspired by the urban legend "[[The Babysitter and the Man Upstairs]]" and a series of murders that took place in the [[Westmount, Quebec|Westmount section]] of [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Moore wrote the screenplay under the title ''Stop Me''. The filmmakers made numerous alterations to the script, primarily the shifting to a university setting with young adult characters. It was shot in Toronto in 1974 on an estimated budget of $620,000, and was distributed by [[Warner Bros.]] in North America. ''Black Christmas'' was released on October 11, 1974 in Canada, and December 20 in the United States under the title ''Silent Night, Evil Night''. It has received critical praise, with film historians noting it for being one of the earliest slasher films{{Cite book |author= Paszylx, Bartłomiej |title=The Pleasure and Pain of Cult Horror Films: An Historical Survey |year=2009 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=978-0-786-43695-8 |pages=135–6}} to conclude without revealing the identity of its villain, as well as serving as an influence on [[John Carpenter]]'s ''[[Halloween (1978 film)|Halloween]]'' (1978). Aside from earning a [[cult following]]{{cite book|last=Jenkins|first=Philip|title=Decade of Nightmares: The End of the Sixties and the Making of Eighties America|year=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-195-34158-4|p=146}} since its release, a novelization written by Lee Hays was published in 1976, and a [[Black Christmas (2006 film)|remake of the same name]], produced by Clark and directed by [[Glen Morgan]], was released in December 2006. ==Plot== An unseen and disoriented man climbs up into the attic of a sorority house, where the tenants are celebrating with a Christmas party. One of the girls, Jess, answers an obscene phone call from a mentally unstable man who is implied to call the house regularly. She summons her fellow students into the room, where they listen as the caller screams and curses them on the phone. When one of the girls, foul-mouthed Barb, takes the phone from Jess, she incites the caller, who in turn promises to kill her. Barb argues with a younger student, Clare Harrison, who implies that the caller could be a serial rapist, before Clare returns to her bedroom to finish packing for Christmas break. The disoriented man lures Clare into her closet, where he suffocates her with a plastic dress bag. He moves her body to the attic. The following morning, Mr. Harrison arrives at the school to pick up his daughter, but she fails to show up to their agreed meeting place. He quickly makes his way to the sorority house, where the housemother, Mrs. MacHenry, is surprised by Clare's absence. Meanwhile, Jess meets her boyfriend, Peter, a neurotic music student. She explains she is pregnant and planning to get an abortion, angering Peter, who attempts to intimidate her. In town, Mr. Harrison, accompanied by Barb and one of the other girls, Phyllis Carlson, attempt to report Clare as missing, while Jess quickly tells Clare's boyfriend Chris about Clare's sudden disappearance. They learn that another local girl named Janis Quaife has also seemingly vanished while walking home from school. After putting a drunken Barb to bed, Mr. Harrison, Chris, Jess, and Phyllis help search for Janis in a nearby park where she allegedly disappeared, hoping to turn up some sign of Clare. Meanwhile, Mrs. Mac plans to leave for her sister's home, only to be lured up into the attic, where she discovers Clare's body. The killer throws a crane hook into her face, hanging and killing her. In the park, Janis's disfigured body is found by the police and Jess returns home, while the search continues for Clare. She answers another obscene phone call and decides to file a report with the police, only for Peter to appear and surprise her. He attempts to persuade her into marriage for the sake of their child, but Jess adamantly refuses. Peter leaves in an emotional state, while Lieutenant Kenneth Fuller arrives to bug the telephone. A group of choir children arrive on the house's stoop to sing Christmas carols, distracting Jess. The killer enters Barb's room and murders her with a glass figurine; Barb's cries for help are drowned out by the singing children. One of the women in charge of the children ushers them away, having learned of Janis's murder. Jess experiences another unnerving phone call, in which the caller restates part of her argument with Peter. Lieutenant Fuller theorizes that Peter could be responsible, due to the caller's knowledge of the argument and his own mental fragility, but Jess doubts this. Moments later, Phyllis enters Barb's room and is ambushed by the killer, who murders her off-screen. Jess gets another obscene phone call, in which the killer alludes to some sort of transgression between two children named Agnes and Billy. The call is long enough to be traced by Graham, a telephone company employee, and Sergeant Nash instructs Jess to leave the house immediately. Concerned for Barb and Phyllis, Jess arms herself with a poker and ventures upstairs, where she discovers Barb and Phyllis's maimed figures. The killer appears and pursues Jess through the house; Jess locks herself in the cellar, only for Peter to appear outside one of the windows. He smashes the window to get to Jess, who proceeds to bludgeon him with the poker, assuming he is the killer. The police arrive moments later, alerted by Jess's screams. They discover her barely conscious in the basement, with Peter's bloody remains next to her. They put Jess to bed and discuss the murders, unaware of Clare and Mrs. MacHenry's bodies still in the attic. Jess is left in the house to rest, with a policeman standing outside. The killer climbs down from the attic as Jess sleeps in a nearby room. The house's telephone begins to ring, leaving Jess's fate unknown as the credits roll. ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Olivia Hussey]] as [[Jess Bradford]] * [[Keir Dullea]] as Peter Smythe * [[Margot Kidder]] as Barbara "Barb" Coard * [[John Saxon]] as Lt. Kenneth Fuller * [[Marian Waldman]] as Mrs. MacHenry * [[Andrea Martin]] as Phyllis "Phyl" Carlson * James Edmond as Mr. Harrison * [[Doug McGrath|Douglas "Doug" McGrath]] as Sergeant Nash * [[Art Hindle|Arthur "Art" Hindle]] as Chris Hayden * [[Lynne Griffin]] as Clare Harrison * Michael Rapport as Patrick Cornell * [[Leslie Carlson|Leslie "Les" Carlson]] as Bill Graham * [[Martha Gibson]] as Mrs. Quaife * John Rutter as laughing detective * David Clement as Cogan {{small|(as Dave Clement)}} * Julian Reed as Officer Jennings * [[Bob Clark]] as Billy's shadow {{dagger}} * [[Nick Mancuso]] as [[Billy (Black Christmas)|Billy]] / phone voice {{dagger}} {{div col end}} {{small| {{dagger}} uncredited}} == Production == ===Concept and writing=== Canadian Roy Moore wrote the screenplay entitled ''Stop Me'' based on "[[The Babysitter and the Man Upstairs]]" urban legend.{{cite web|author=Smith, Richard Harland |title=Black Christmas (1974)|url=http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/410638%7C0/Black-Christmas.html|work=[[Turner Classic Movies]]|accessdate=December 18, 2016}} Moore also claimed to have been inspired by a series of murders that occurred during the holiday season in the [[Westmount, Quebec|Westmount]] area of [[Montreal]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/homegrown-horror-5-canadian-scary-movies-you-need-to-watch-this-halloween-1.3825829|work=Canadian Broadcasting Company|title=Homegrown horror: 5 Canadian scary movies you need to watch this Halloween|date=October 28, 2016|author=Dupuis, Chris|accessdate=November 19, 2017}}{{additional citations needed|date=May 2018}} Film producers Harvey Sherman and Richard Schouten had Timothy Bond rewrite the script to give it a university setting.{{cite av media|title=Black Christmas Legacy|work=Black Christmas|format=Blu-ray|medium=Documentary|publisher=Scream Factory|year=2016}} Clark, who had felt the original script was too much of a straightforward slasher film, made several alterations in dialogue, and also incorporated humorous elements into the film, particularly the drunkenness of Barb, and Mrs. Mac, who Clark based on his aunt. Clark felt that college and high school students had not been depicted with "any sense of reality" in American film, and that he intended to capture the "astuteness" of young adults: "College students—even in 1974—are astute people. They're not fools. It's not all "bikinis, beach blankets, [and] bingo"." ===Casting=== [[File:Black Christmas main cast.png|thumb|right|upright|The central cast of ''Black Christmas'' {{small|(clockwise from left to right)}}: Olivia Hussey, Keir Dullea, John Saxon, and Margot Kidder]] Olivia Hussey, who had previously garnered international fame for her role as Juliet in [[Franco Zeffirelli]]'s ''[[Romeo and Juliet (1968 film)|Romeo and Juliet]]'' (1968), signed on to appear in the film after being told by a [[psychic]] that she would "make a film in Canada that would earn a great deal of money." Clark sought Keir Dullea to play the role of Peter based on his performance as Dave Bowman in ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' (1968). The role of Mrs. Mac was offered to [[Bette Davis]], who declined the part. Margot Kidder was cast in the role of Barb, and said she had been attracted to the character "because she was wild and out of control", and not a "conventional leading" part. [[Gilda Radner]] was offered the role of Phyllis Carlson; she accepted the part, but dropped out one month before filming began owing to ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' commitments, and was replaced by Andrea Martin. The role of Lieutenant Fuller was originally given to [[Edmond O'Brien]]. Upon his arrival to the set, however, the producers realized he would be unable to fulfill the duties required of the part due to his failing health (stemming from [[Alzheimer's disease]]).{{cite web|title=13 Things You Didn't Know About 'Black Christmas'|url=http://www.chillertv.com/friday13/13-things-you-didn%E2%80%99t-know-about-black-christmas|work=[[Chiller (TV channel)]]|date=December 25, 2015|deadurl=yes|archivedate=December 29, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151229181231/http://www.chillertv.com/friday13/13-things-you-didn%E2%80%99t-know-about-black-christmas|df=}} John Saxon, who had read the script prior, was called by the producers who offered him the role; he accepted, and had to arrive in Toronto from New York City within two days to begin shooting. ===Filming=== [[File:Harthouse night.jpg|thumb|upright=1|left|[[Soldiers' Tower]] at the [[University of Toronto]] is featured in the film]] ''Black Christmas'' was shot on location in [[Toronto]] in the winter of 1973–74; the house featured in the film had been discovered by Clark while scouting for locations, and its owners agreed to lease the home for the production. Additional photography was completed on the [[University of Toronto]] campus. According to John Saxon, Clark had meticulously drawn out storyboards with key shots, which he brought to the film set each day: "I could understand exactly what I thought he needed, and the scene needed." Margot Kidder remembers making the film was "fun. I really bonded with Andrea Martin, filming in Toronto and Ontario. Olivia Hussey was a bit of an odd one. She was obsessed with the idea of falling in love with [[Paul McCartney]] through her psychic. We were a little hard on her for things like that."{{cite web|title=Random Roles: Margot Kidder|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/random-roles-margot-kidder-24554|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=March 3, 2009|accessdate=December 18, 2016}} ===Post-production=== The composer of the film's score, Carl Zittrer, stated in an interview that he created the film's mysterious music by tying forks, combs, and knives onto the strings of the piano to warp the sound of the keys. Zittrer also stated that he would distort the sound further by recording its sound onto an audio tape and make the sound slower. The audio for the disturbing phone calls was performed by multiple actors including actor [[Nick Mancuso]] and director Bob Clark. Mancuso stated in an interview that he stood on his head during the recording sessions to compress his [[thorax]] and make his voice sound more demented.{{cite web|title=Slay bells ring: an interview with Black Christmas stars Lynne Griffin, Nick Mancuso and Doug McGrath|url=http://www.the-filmreel.com/2015/11/24/slay-bells-ring-an-interview-with-black-christmas-stars-lynne-griffin-nick-mancuso-and-doug-mcgrath/|work=The Film Reel|accessdate=December 18, 2016|date=November 24, 2015}} During preparation in 1975 for the film's American release, [[Warner Bros.]] studio executives asked Clark to change the concluding scene to show Clare's boyfriend, Chris, appear in front of Jess and say, "Agnes, don't tell them what we did" before killing her; however, Clark insisted on keeping the ending ambiguous. The original title of the film was initially planned to be ''Stop Me''. Clark has stated in an interview that he came up with the film's official title, saying that he enjoyed the irony of a dark event occurring during a festive holiday. According to Clark as well, Warner Bros. changed the title to ''Silent Night, Evil Night'', for the United States theatrical release. ==Release== ===Theatrical distribution=== ''Black Christmas'' was officially released on October 11, 1974, in Canada through Ambassador Film Distributors. In the United States, [[Warner Bros.]] released the film in tandem with the [[Christmas]] season on December 20, 1974.{{cite web|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|title=Black Christmas (1974)|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=blackchristmas74.htm|accessdate=November 19, 2017}} For the American release, Warner Bros. initially changed the title to ''Silent Night, Evil Night'', worried that the original title would mislead audiences into believing the film was a [[blaxploitation]] movie. They retracted the title after the initial release, restoring it to ''Black Christmas'' for subsequent screenings. The film later screened in October 1975 in New York City and Chicago,{{cite news |title=Screen: Murky Whodunit; 'Black Christmas' Is at Local Theaters|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 20, 1975|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0E12F63E5C1A7493C2AB178BD95F418785F9|accessdate= June 4, 2012}} as well as 19 theaters in Los Angeles, where it generated considerable ticket sales. This prompted Warner Bros. to expand the release to a total of 70 theaters nationwide in time for Halloween, but the film only generated a daily average of $700 per theater, per day, after which Warner Bros. withdrew the film from circulation in December.{{cite book|title=Blood Money: A History of the First Teen Slasher Film Cycle|p=77|author=Nowell, Richard|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic|year=2010|isbn=978-1-441-12496-8}} The film had previously screened under the alternate title ''Silent Night, Evil Night'' in Virginia in July 1975.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Edward|title=Horror Cliches: Up from the Dead, and Still Fun|newspaper=[[The Free Lance–Star]]|date= July 14, 1975|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uIgTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KosDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1021,2184693&dq=silent-night-evil-night&hl=en|accessdate=4 June 2012}} Overall, ''Black Christmas'' grossed over $4,053,000 internationally, managing to earn more than its budget of $620,000.{{cite web|last=Justice|first=Chris|title=Black Christmas (1974)|url=http://classic-horror.com/reviews/black_christmas_1974|publisher=Classic-Horror|date=October 27, 2006}} When released in the [[United Kingdom|UK]], the [[BBFC]] had the word "cunt" removed, as well as several other crude and sexual references during the first obscene phone call.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} ===Television premiere controversy=== The film, under the title ''Stranger in the House'', was set to make its network television premiere on Saturday night, January 28, 1978, on [[NBC]]'s weekly "Saturday Night at the Movies". Two weeks prior to its premiere, the [[Chi Omega]] Sorority House on the campus of [[Florida State University]] in [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]] was the scene of a double murder in which two Chi Omega sisters, asleep in their beds, were bludgeoned to death. The killer then went to a nearby room in the sorority house and violently attacked two more sleeping co-eds, who survived. The killer was later identified as [[Ted Bundy]], who was executed for this and other homicides on January 24, 1989.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/134823910/?terms=%22Stranger%2Bin%2Bthe%2BHouse%22|title=Network Offers TV Alternative for Terror Film|last=Associated Press|first=|date=January 25, 1978|work=The Palm Beach Post|page=61|access-date=July 14, 2016|via=Newspapers.com}} A few days before the movie was set to premiere on network television Florida's then-Governor [[Reubin Askew]] contacted NBC President Robert Mullholland to request the movie not be shown due to its all-too-similar theme as the murders of sorority sisters by an unknown madman at the Chi Omega Sorority House. On Tuesday, January 24, NBC-TV gave several of its affiliates in Florida, Georgia, and Alabama, the option of showing an alternate movie, ''[[Doc Savage: The Man of Bronze]]'', in place of ''Stranger in the House.''." "The network said in a statement issued yesterday in New York City that it was responding to concern voiced by the affiliates because of the murder of two coeds this month in a sorority house at Florida State University in Tallahassee." ==Home video== ''Black Christmas'' has been released on [[DVD]] several times in North America. A 25th Anniversary edition was released in Canada on November 6, 2001 by Critical Mass.{{cite web|url=https://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/5126/black-christmas-25th-anniversary/|work=DVD Talk|title=Black Christmas 25th Anniversary: DVD|accessdate=November 19, 2017}} This edition only contains the theatrical trailer as a bonus feature.{{cite av media|title=Black Christmas|publisher=Critical Mass|year=2001|format=DVD}} The following year, on December 3, 2002, Critical Mass released a Collector's Edition of the film on DVD with making-of documentaries, two audio commentary tracks, and reversible English and French cover artwork.{{cite av media|title=Black Christmas|publisher=Critical Mass|year=2002|isbn=1-55259-366-5|format=DVD}} On December 5, 2006, Critical Mass released a third "Special Edition" DVD with a newly remastered transfer, two original scenes with newly-uncovered vocal tracks, a new documentary on the making of the film, and cast and crew interviews.{{cite av media|title=Black Christmas|year=2006|publisher=Critical Mass|format=DVD}} This edition was later released on [[Blu-ray]] on November 11, 2008.{{cite web|work=Blu-ray.com|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/Black-Christmas-Blu-ray/1164/|title=Black Christmas Blu-ray|accessdate=November 19, 2017}} Soon after the film's 40th anniversary, [[Anchor Bay Entertainment|Anchor Bay]] released a Blu-ray and DVD in Canada, titled the "Season's Grievings Edition". It contains the same transfer of the film as the "Special Edition" release and all previous bonus content, plus the addition of: a new documentary ("Black Christmas Legacy"), a 40th anniversary panel from [[Fan Expo Canada|Fan Expo]] 2014, a new commentary track featuring [[Nick Mancuso]] as the character "Billy", a new retrospective booklet written by [[Rue Morgue (magazine)|Rue Morgue Magazine]], and new packaging art by Gary Pullin ([[art director]] of Rue Morgue Magazine). This new edition was released on Blu-ray and DVD on November 24, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.fangoria.com/new/exclusive-trailer-anchor-bay-canadas-black-christmas-blu-ray-seasons-grievings-edition/|work=Fangoria|title=Exclusive Trailer: Anchor Bay Canada's "BLACK CHRISTMAS" Blu-ray, 'Seasons Grievings' Edition!|date=October 15, 2015|accessdate=November 20, 2017|author=Hanley, Ken W.}} In the United States, [[Scream Factory]] released the film in a collector's edition Blu-ray on December 13, 2016 with a new transfer and new extras.{{cite web|work=DVD Talk|url=https://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/71725/black-christmas-collectors-edition/|title=Black Christmas: Collector's Edition|author=Spurlin, Thomas|date=January 20, 2017|accessdate=November 20, 2017}} The Scream Factory release collates all of the bonus materials from the previous releases by Critical Mass and Anchor Bay, and also features the 2006 Critical Mass restoration of the film in the bonus materials. ==Reception== During its initial release, the film had garnered mixed reviews. A writer for ''[[The New York Times]]'' scored the film a 1 out of 5, calling it "a whodunit that raises the question as to why was it made."{{Cite news |date= October 20, 1975 |title=Screen: Murky Whodunit: 'Black Christmas' Is at Local Theaters |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9504E3D71538EF34BC4851DFB667838E669EDE |accessdate= June 4, 2012}} {{rating|1|5}} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called the film "a bloody, senseless kill-for-kicks feature, [that] exploits unnecessary violence in a university sorority house operated by an implausibly alcoholic ex-hoofer. Its slow-paced, murky tale involves an obscene telephone caller who apparently delights in killing the girls off one by one, even the hapless house-mother."{{cite web|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|title=Black Christmas|date=December 31, 1974|accessdate=November 18, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231231035/http://variety.com/1973/film/reviews/black-christmas-1200423278/|archivedate=December 31, 2013|url=https://variety.com/1973/film/reviews/black-christmas-1200423278/}} According to review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], it currently holds a 70% approval rating, based on 30 reviews, with the consensus reading: "The rare slasher with enough intelligence to wind up the tension between bloody outbursts, ''Black Christmas'' offers fiendishly enjoyable holiday viewing for genre fans."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1002484-black_christmas/ |title=Black Christmas (1974) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=4 June 2012}} Heidi Martinuzzi of ''[[Film Threat]]'' called the film "innovative" and praised the leading actresses, [[Olivia Hussey]] and [[Margot Kidder]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmthreat.com/reviews/6782/ |title=Black Christmas |work=[[Film Threat]] |date= December 24, 2004|accessdate=June 4, 2012}} ''[[TV Guide]]'' awarded the film three out of four stars, writing: "Although strictly standard fare, the material is elevated somewhat through Clark's skillful handling of such plot devices as obscene phone calls from the killer to the girls via the upstairs phone and a nicely handled twist ending, which provides a genuine shock."{{cite web|work=[[TV Guide]]|title=Black Christmas (1974) Review|accessdate=November 20, 2017|url=http://www.tvguide.com/movies/black-christmas/review/108583/}} {{rating|3|4}} Author and film critic [[Leonard Maltin]] gave the film his usual two and a half out of a possible four stars (his most frequently given rating) calling it "bizarre" but also praised Kidder's performance as a standout.{{cite book|last1=Maltin|first1=Leonard|last2=Carson|first2=Darwyn|last3=Sader|first3=Luke|title=Leonard Maltin's 2014 Movie Guide|publisher=Penguin Press|isbn=978-0-451-41810-4|page=137}} The ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' film guide noted that the film "manages a good slice of old-fashioned suspense."{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/67908/black_christmas.html|work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]|location=London|title=Black Christmas|accessdate=November 9, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107083055/http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/67908/black_christmas.html|archivedate=November 7, 2012}} ==Accolades== '''[[Saturn Award|Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy & Horror Films]]''' * 1976: Nominated, "Best Horror Film" '''[[Canadian Film Awards]]''' * 1975: Won, "Best Sound Editing in a Feature" – Kenneth Heeley-Ray{{cite journal|work=[[Cinema Canada]]|issue=18–24|year=1975|p=25|title=Canadian Film Awards|publisher=Cinema Canada Magazine Foundation}} * 1975: Won, "Best Performance by a Lead Actress" – [[Margot Kidder]]{{cite book|title=Guide to the Cinema(s) of Canada|editor=Rist, Peter|p=112|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=2001|isbn=978-0-313-29931-5}} * 1975: Nominee, [[Canadian Screen Award for Best Motion Picture|Best Feature Film]]{{cite news|title=Best-film showdown: 11 vie for all-Canadian honours |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/18703453/|newspaper=[[Ottawa Journal]]|date=October 3, 1975|page=39|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = March 28, 2018 }} {{free access}} '''[[Edgar Allan Poe Awards]]''' * 1976: Nominated, "Best Motion Picture" – A. Roy Moore{{cite book|title=The Christmas Encyclopedia|edition=3rd|p=43|author=Crump, William D.|year=2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn= 978-1-476-60573-9}} ==Legacy== The film eventually gained a [[cult following]] and is notable for being one of the earliest [[slasher films]]. It went on to inspire other slasher films, the biggest being [[John Carpenter]]'s ''[[Halloween (1978 film)|Halloween]]'' (which was apparently inspired by Clark suggesting what a ''Black Christmas'' sequel would be like).{{cite web|last=Squires|first=John|title=How 'Halloween' Was Basically an Unofficial 'Black Christmas' Sequel|url=http://bloody-disgusting.com/editorials/3413469/halloween-basically-unofficial-black-christmas-sequel|date=November 11, 2016}}{{cite episode|people=Orchard, Tristan (dir.); Clark, Bob; Kidder, Margot; Dullea, Keir; et al.|series=On Screen!|publisher=Canadian Television Fund|title= Black Christmas|airdate=July 22, 2005|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1074369/}}{{sfn|Muir|2011|p=315}} The film ranked No. 87 on ''[[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo]]'''s ''[[The 100 Scariest Movie Moments]]''.{{cite web|last=Dirks|first=Tim|title=Greatest Scariest Movie Moments and Scenes (B)|url=http://www.filmsite.org/scariestscenes2.html|publisher=AMC Filmsite}} Olivia Hussey told [[Bravo (U.S. TV network)|Bravo]] during an interview about their 100 Scariest Movie Moments series, that when she met [[Steve Martin]] for the first time, he told her she starred in his favorite movie of all time. Hussey initially thought he was referring to ''[[Romeo and Juliet (1968 film)|Romeo and Juliet]]'' but was surprised when Martin said it was ''Black Christmas'' and that he had seen the film 27 times.{{cite web|last=Stitzel|first=Kelly|title=Horror Movie Marathon: Part The Last|url=http://popdose.com/horror-movie-marathon-part-the-last/|publisher=Popdose|date=October 31, 2012}} The film has been assessed in [[feminist film theory]], with viewers arguing that the female-led cast, presence of casual sexual activity, and plot elements of obscene phone calls and abortion provide feminist subtext.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/culture/2016/12/22/13872376/skip-die-hard-watch-black-christmas|title=Skip Die Hard this year. Black Christmas is the cynical 2016 holiday movie alternative.|work=Vox|access-date=July 12, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://thetfs.ca/article/dreaming-of-a-black-christmas-revisiting-the-canadian-classic-that-changed-the-horror-genre/|title=Dreaming of a Black Christmas: revisiting the canadian classic that changed the horror genre|work= Toronto Film Scene|date=April 19, 2015|access-date=July 12, 2017|author=Cooper, Kristal|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419055400/http://thetfs.ca/article/dreaming-of-a-black-christmas-revisiting-the-Canadian-classic-that-changed-the-horror-genre/|archivedate=April 19, 2015|df=}} ==Related works== A novelization of the film written by Lee Hays was published in 1976 by Popular Library.{{cite book|author=Hays, Lee|title=Black Christmas|year=1976|publisher=Popular Library|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/8568273-black-christmas}} A [[Black Christmas (2006 film)|remake of the film]], directed by [[Glen Morgan]], was released on December 25, 2006. It is loosely based on the original film, containing more graphic content and a focus into the past of Billy. [[Andrea Martin]] was the only original cast member to appear in the film. [[Bob Clark]] served as an [[Executive producer#Motion pictures and television|executive producer]].{{cite web|work=Variety|url=https://variety.com/2007/film/markets-festivals/bob-clark-67-director-1117962526/|title=Bob Clark, 67, director|date=April 4, 2007|author=Garrett, Diane|accessdate=November 19, 2017}} ==See also== * [[List of films featuring home invasions]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Works cited== *{{cite book|last=Muir|first=John Kenneth|author-link=John Kenneth Muir|title=Horror Films of the 1970s|year=2011|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-786-49156-8|ref=harv}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|id=0071222|title=Black Christmas}} * {{Allmovie title|5838|Black Christmas}} * {{mojo title|blackchristmas74|Black Christmas}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|id=1002484-black_christmas|title=Black Christmas}} * {{tcmdb title|68859|Black Christmas}} {{Black Christmas}} {{Bob Clark}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Black Christmas (1974 Film)}} [[Category:1974 films]] [[Category:1974 horror films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:1970s psychological films]] [[Category:1970s slasher films]] [[Category:Warner Bros. films]] [[Category:Films directed by Bob Clark]] [[Category:Canadian films]] [[Category:Canadian independent films]] [[Category:Canadian psychological films]] [[Category:Canadian slasher films]] [[Category:Canadian Christmas films]] [[Category:Canadian serial killer films]] [[Category:Christmas horror films]] [[Category:Psychological horror films]] [[Category:Films based on urban legends]] [[Category:Films about fraternities and sororities]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:Home invasions in film]] [[Category:Pregnancy films]] [[Category:Films shot in Toronto]]
